facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 624 of 1960 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 624 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated May 30, 1960 of Mysore High Court in Civil Revision Petition No. 1098 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 30, 1960 of the Mysore High Court in Civil Revision Petition No. 1098 of 1959.

facts.text: Smt. Vimala filed suit No. 73 of 1956 in the court of the Subordinate Judge, South Kanara.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH, J.-Smt. Vimla-hereinafter referred to as the plaintiff-filed suit No. 73 of 1956 in the court of the Subordinate Judge, South Kanara,

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed decree for possession of lands, buildings, house-sites in sch. A and movable properties in sch. B.

anchor.surface_text: for a decree for possession of lands, buildings, house-sites described in sch. A and movable properties described in sch. B and for mesne profits in respect of properties described in sch. A

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed decree for possession, management and account of properties in sch. C and institutions in sch. D alleged to be private family religious endowments.

anchor.surface_text: and for a decree for possession and management and for account of the properties described in sch. C and institutions alleged to be the private family religious endowments in sch. D.

facts.text: Shri Dharmasthala Manjayya Heggade died on August 31, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff claimed that on the death of her father Shri Dharmasthala Manjayya Heggade on August 31, 1955,

facts.text: Plaintiff became entitled to the properties in suit upon father's death.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff claimed that on the death of her father Shri Dharmasthala Manjayya Heggade on August 31, 1955, she became entitled to the properties in suit

facts.text: Defendant wrongfully possessed himself of the properties.

anchor.surface_text: but the defendant wrongfully possessed himself of those properties.

facts.text: Plaintiff valued properties in schs. C and D under s. 28 of Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955 at Rs. 21,000/- and paid court-fee of Rs. 275/-

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff valued the properties in schs. C and D under s. 28 of the Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act, 1955 at Rs. 21,000/- and paid a court-fee of Rs. 275/-

facts.text: Plaintiff valued lands in schedule A for jurisdiction at 30 times the assessment.

anchor.surface_text: . She valued the lands in schedule A for purposes of jurisdiction at 30 times the assessment and separately valued the buildings

facts.text: On June 28, 1956, Subordinate Judge ordered that Rs. 34,577/- paid as court-fee was adequate on office objection.

anchor.surface_text: On June 28, 1956, the Subordinate Judge ordered on an objection raised by his office that the amount of Rs. 34,577/- paid as court-fee by the plaintiff was adequate.

facts.text: Defendant filed written statement on September 9, 1956 raising objection to valuation and court-fee.

anchor.surface_text: On September 9, 1956, the defendant filed his written statement raising an objection inter alia to the valuation of the properties in suit and the court-fee exigible on the claim.

facts.text: Trial court raised issue about adequacy of court-fee paid by plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court then raised an issue about the adequacy of the court-fee, paid by the plaintiff.

facts.text: On February 13, 1957, defendant applied for appointment of Commissioner to value properties.

anchor.surface_text: On February 13, 1957, the defendant applied for the appointment of a Commissioner to value the properties.

facts.text: Trial court dismissed application for commissioner and declared court-fee adequate.

anchor.surface_text: The court dismissed the application and declared that the court- fee paid was adequate.

facts.text: Defendant preferred Revision Petition 272 of 1957 to High Court of Judicature at Bangalore.

anchor.surface_text: In Revision Petition 272 of 1957 preferred by the defendant to the High Court of Judicature at Bangalore, the order passed by the Subordinate Judge was set aside

facts.text: High Court set aside Subordinate Judge's order and directed trial court to ascertain value for court-fee, appoint commissioner if needed.

anchor.surface_text: and it was directed that the trial court do ascertain the value of the properties for purposes of court- fee in accordance with law after giving full opportunity to the parties and if need be by appointing a Commissioner

facts.text: Subordinate Judge appointed a Commissioner pursuant to High Court direction.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this direction, a Commissioner was appointed by the Subordinate Judge.

facts.text: Commissioner submitted report on valuation; defendant raised objections; further and supplemental reports submitted.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner submitted his report as to valuation of the properties. Objections were raised by the defendant to that report and a further report was submitted by the Commissioner. On the direction of the Subordinate Judge, a supplemental report was submitted by the Commissioner.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held properties in sch. D were extra commercial, fixed court-fee for possession; sch. D trust properties, s.28 applies; houses on revenue lands at market value; lands sch. A worth Rs. 7,74,665/-; house-sites Rs. 27,625/-

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the parties, the Subordinate Judge held that the properties described in sch. D were extra commercial and fixed court-fee was exigible in respect of the claim for possession thereof, that properties described in sch. D were trust properties and s. 28 of the Madras Court-fees and Suits Valuation Act applied thereto as the dispute related to the right of management between persons claiming to be rival trustees, that the houses built on revenue paying lands had to be valued according to their market value and lands in sch. A were worth Rs. 7,74,665/- and the house-sites were worth Rs. 27,625/-

facts.text: Plaintiff paid additional court-fee as directed.

anchor.surface_text: . The plaintiff paid the additional court-fee as directed by the court,

facts.text: Plaintiff and defendant filed separate revision petitions to High Court of Mysore against Subordinate Judge's order.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the Subordinate Judge, the plaintiff and the defendant applied by separate petitions in revision to the High Court of Mysore.

facts.text: High Court heard Advocate-General of the State and confirmed Subordinate Judge's order except for Nelliyadi Beedu.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court heard the Advocate-General of the State and substantially confirmed the order passed by the Subordinate Judge except as to an institution described as Nelliyadi Beedu

facts.text: High Court directed trial court to determine if Nelliyadi Beedu was extra commercial after hearing parties and evidence.

anchor.surface_text: , in respect of which the High Court directed the trial court to determine whether the institution was extra commercial after giving an opportunity to both parties to put forth their contentions and to lead evidence in that behalf.

facts.text: Defendant preferred appeal to Supreme Court with special leave under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order of the High Court, this appeal has been preferred by the defendant with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 27, 1961 by SHAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: On Notice issued by the Court . 1961. February 27. The Judgment, of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-
Against that order of the High Court, this appeal has been preferred by the defendant with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: But counsel for the defendant says that by Act 14 of 1955 enacted by the Madras Legislature which applied to the suit in question, the defendant has been invested with a right not only to contest in the trial court the issue whether adequate court-fee has been paid by the plaintiff, but also to move the High Court in revision if an order contrary to his submission is passed by the court. Reliance in support of that contention is placed upon sub-s. (2) of s. 12.

anchor.surface_text: The Act, it is true by s. 19, provides that for the purpose of deciding whether the subject-matter of the suit or other proceeding has been properly valued or whether the fee paid is sufficient, the court may hold such enquiry as it considers proper and issue a commission to any other person directing him to make such local or other investigation as may be necessary and report thereon.

anchor.surface_text: Whether proper court-fee is paid on a plaint is primarily a question between the plaintiff and the State. How by an order relating to the adequacy of the court-fee paid by the plaintiff, the defendant may feel aggrieved, it is difficult to appreciate.

concepts.interpretation: Adequacy of court-fee is matter between plaintiff and State; defendant has no grievance or right to challenge via revision

concepts.unlisted_description: Category under Madras Court-fees Act for religious endowments or trusts attracting special valuation under s.28

anchor.surface_text: The Court-fees Act was enacted to collect revenue for the benefit of the State and not to arm a contesting party with a weapon of defence to obstruct the trial of an action. By recognising that the defendant was entitled to contest the valuation of the properties in dispute as if it were a matter in issue between him and the plaintiff and by entertaining petitions preferred by the defendant to the High Court in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction against the order adjudging court-fee payable on the plaint, all progress in the suit for the trial of the dispute on the merits has been effectively frustrated for nearly five years.

concepts.interpretation: Purpose is revenue collection for State, not to provide defendant weapon to delay trial

issues.text: what grievance the defendant can make by seeking to invoke the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court on the question whether the plaintiff has paid adequate court-fee on his plaint

anchor.surface_text: We fail to appreciate what grievance the defendant can make by seeking to invoke the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court on the question whether the plaintiff has paid adequate court- fee on his plaint. Whether proper court-fee is paid on a plaint is primarily a question between the plaintiff and the State.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court heard the Advocate-General of the State and substantially confirmed the order passed by the Subordinate Judge except as to an institution described as Nelliyadi Beedu , in respect of which the High Court directed the trial court to determine whether the institution was extra commercial after giving an opportunity to both parties to put forth their contentions and to lead evidence in that behalf. Against that order of the High Court, this appeal has been preferred by the defendant with special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: The Court-fees Act was enacted to collect revenue for the benefit of the State and not to arm a contesting party with a weapon of defence to obstruct the trial of an action.

anchor.surface_text: The Court-fees Act was enacted to collect revenue for the benefit of the State and not to arm a contesting party with a weapon of defence to obstruct the trial of an action. By recognising that the defendant was entitled to contest the valuation of the properties in dispute as if it were a matter in issue between him and the plaintiff and by entertaining petitions preferred by the defendant to the High Court in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction against the order adjudging court-fee payable on the plaint, all progress in the suit for the trial of the dispute on the merits has been effectively frustrated for nearly five years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative purpose is revenue collection; allowing defendant challenges obstructs trial.

holdings.text: Defendant has no grievance to invoke High Court revisional jurisdiction on adequacy of court-fee paid by plaintiff; it is primarily a question between plaintiff and State.

anchor.surface_text: We fail to appreciate what grievance the defendant can make by seeking to invoke the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court on the question whether the plaintiff has paid adequate court- fee on his plaint. Whether proper court-fee is paid on a plaint is primarily a question between the plaintiff and the State. How by an order relating to the adequacy of the court-fee paid by the plaintiff, the defendant may feel aggrieved, it is difficult to appreciate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adequacy of court-fee concerns plaintiff-State relationship; defendant lacks standing.

holdings.text: Jurisdiction in revision under s.115 CPC strictly conditioned by clauses (a) to (c); defendant has no right to move superior court against order on court-fee adequacy.

anchor.surface_text: Again, the jurisdiction in revision exercised by the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure is strictly conditioned by cls. a to c thereof and may be invoked on the ground of refusal to exercise jurisdiction vested in the Subordinate Court or assumption of jurisdiction which the court does not possess or on the ground that the court has acted illegally or with material irregularity in the exercise of its jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revision limited to jurisdictional errors or irregularities; court-fee order does not qualify.

holdings.text: Act 14 of 1955 s.12(2) enables defendant only to plead in written statement and assist trial court on court-fee; no provision enables defendant to move High Court in revision.

anchor.surface_text: But counsel for the defendant says that by Act 14 of 1955 enacted by the Madras Legislature which applied to the suit in question, the defendant has been invested with a right not only to contest in the trial court the issue whether adequate court-fee has been paid by the plaintiff, but also to move the High Court in revision if an order contrary to his submission is passed by the court. Reliance in support of that contention is placed upon sub-s. (2) of s. 12.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.12(2) limited to trial court pleading and assistance; no revisional right conferred; s.19 allows enquiry but not defendant revision.

holdings.text: High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on questions of court-fee at the instance of the defendant.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on questions of court-fee at the instance of the defend.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combining above: no standing, no jurisdictional basis under s.115, no statutory right under Madras Act.

justification_sets.label: Section 115, Code of Civil Procedure support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on questions of court-fee at the instance of the defend.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court erred in entertaining revision applications on questions of court-fee at the instance of the defendant

anchor.surface_text: We fail to appreciate what grievance the defendant can make by seeking to invoke the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court on the question whether the plaintiff has paid adequate court- fee on his plaint. Whether proper court-fee is paid on a plaint is primarily a question between the plaintiff and the State. How by an order relating to the adequacy of the court-fee paid by the plaintiff, the defendant may feel aggrieved, it is difficult to appreciate.
In our view, the High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on questions of court-fee at the instance of the defend.
ed to companylect revenue for the benefit of the State and number to arm a companytesting party with a weapon of defence to obstruct the trial of an a

edges.explanation: Holding denying s.115 jurisdiction to defendant directly addresses the issue

anchor.surface_text: Again, the jurisdiction in revision exercised by the High Court under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure is strictly conditioned by cls. a to c thereof and may be invoked on the ground of refusal to exercise jurisdiction vested in the Subordinate Court or assumption of jurisdiction which the court does not possess or on the ground that the court has acted illegally or with material irregularity in the exercise of its jurisdiction.
In our view, the High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on questions of court-fee at the instance of the defend.
eking to invoke the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court on the question whether the plaintiff has paid adequate companyrt- fee on his plaint. Wh

anchor.surface_text: frustrated for nearly five years. We fail to appreciate what grievance the defendant can make by seeking to invoke the revisional jurisdiction of the

edges.explanation: Holding h4 directly resolves the issue i3 on rights under Act 14 of 1955 s.12(2), with overlapping character ranges.

anchor.surface_text: But counsel for the defendant says that by Act 14 of 1955 enacted by the Madras Legislature which applied to the suit in question, the defendant has been invested with a right not only to contest in the trial court the issue whether adequate court-fee has been paid by the plaintiff, but also to move the High Court in revision if an order contrary to his submission is passed by the court. Reliance in support of that contention is placed upon sub-s. (2) of s. 12.
In our view, the High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on questions of court-fee at the instance of the defend.
In our view, the High Court grievously erred in entertaining revision applications on questions of court-fee at the instance of the defend.
